messages.content:
To allow users of my ZK App to store sensistive metadata in a public storage network (IPFS) I need to ensure the data is encrypted.
This process should not be done by a central server, but client-side.

Users are authenticated with their Auro Wallet, which does not support any kind of encryption.
However I was thinking in creating the encryptions keys from the Nullifier, since it is not dynamic or random.

I am looking for recommendations of good practices / papers / suggestions based on this method. Although I do not see any vulnerabilities in that method, I would like to be sure that I am applying some technique that has already been studied.

Can you elaborate on :
"However I was thinking of creating the encryption keys from the Nullifier, since it is not dynamic or random."
Specifically about the nullifier. Did you mean private key?

What encryption method do you want to use?
We currently support nullifier encryption.
nullifier Docs:
https://docs.aurowallet.com/general/howto/create-nullifier
nullifier Demo
https://github.com/aurowallet/test-zkapp/blob/master/ui/src/components/HomeComponents/CreateNullifierBox.tsx#L20

Sure, Auro Wallet create nullifiers. I mean creating a private key using the nullifier.

It has no implications for the Auro Wallet itself.
I mean create a nullifier and use it as a private key for encryption

I believe I could use any symmetric encryption like AES256. But for documentation purposes I would like to have a better definition for this process, does that is a common practice, doest that process have a name? (The process of generating Nullifiers and using it as private key for symmetric encryption)

The process of using nullifiers in cryptographic systems is most commonly associated with ZKPs, particularly in privacy-preserving blockchain applications. However, using nullifiers specifically as symmetric encryption keys isn't a standard cryptographic practice in the traditional sense afaik

Also what I do feel is if nullifiers are deterministically generated, they may be more predictable than cryptographically secure random keys, an attacker who understands the nullifier generation pattern could potentially predict future keys

if that were true than Nullifiers would not be safe.
I think Nullifiers cannot be predicted.
mmm yea nullifiers are cryptographically secure against external prediction but It's not about them being insecure in general, but about using them for a purpose they weren't designed for
Maybe someone more educated about this can help you better
I think a real issue is that since it was designed to be public, can be easy to convince users to generate their nullifier (private key) in malicious app.
lol yeah
You can as an alternative get a signature from a wallet, add some salt and supply it to one of the many crypto schemes available from the crypto web api
@br0wnD3v I think Mina will generate random signatures everytime, it’s not constant like nullifiers, so will not possible
as long as you keep the salt same it wont
And the data that gets signed, if its constant the output should come out the same as well
Did you try this though? Or it's based on gut feeling??? Just curious :)
Good to know. I actually just presumed because it’s based in schnorr
Correct me if I am wrong, you just want a safe way to have asymmetric encryption over ipfs data right?
based on each new private key
I mean per wallet address
Actually a key to symmetric encryption like AES.
But if it works for symmetric also can works for asymmetric
yeah, in my tests the same signature was generated 3 times
Yep yep
